Replies.Reply: You have a choice in this world, I believe, about how to tell sad stories.
On the one hand, you can sugar coat - the way they do in movies and romance novels.
I like that way as much as the next girl, believe me. It's just not the truth.
Which is what was happening to me.
like the Keith Richards of cancer kids.
I'm not sure it's for me.
I'll spare you the gory details of Patrick's ball cancer. Basically, they found it in his nuts, cut most of it out, he almost died, but he didn't die, and now here he is -
Thyroid originally but with quite the impressive satellite colony in my lungs.
You mean besides the terminal cancer?
Why don't you guys go to a movie?
You haven't been out in a while.
Reality shows. Doctor's appointments. Eight prescription drugs, three times a day.
If you want me to be a teenager, don't send me to Support Group. Buy me a fake ID so I can go to clubs and drink gimlets and take pot.
See, that's the kind of thing I would know with a fake ID.
Are you gonna sit here and wait the whole time?
The only thing worse than biting it from cancer - is having a kid bite it from cancer.
Oblivion's inevitable. And if that scares you, well, I suggest you ignore it. God knows it's what everyone else does.
Someone should probably tell him, don't you think? Jesus? Seems kinda dangerous keeping all these kids with cancer in your heart.
Why are you looking at me like that?
He's gotta be hurting her boob.
You could be an axe murderer.
Oh my god. Oh. My. God. You're kidding right?
You just ruined the whole thing!

What, you think that's cool? Oh you idiot! There's always a hamartia, isn't there? And yours is - even though you had FREAKING CANCER you give money to a corporation for the chance to acquire EVEN MORE CANCER!? Ugh. And you were doing so well.
I've made plans with Augustus Waters.
I'm surprised you have a license.
I was 13 when they found it.
All of which worked for a while.
And then my lungs started filling up with water.
That should have been the end.
The antibiotics kicked in. They drained the fluid from my lungs.
I even found myself in an experimental trial. You know the ones that are famous in the Republic of Cancervania for not working.
Of course my lungs still suck but, theoretically, they could continue to suck in just this way for, I dunno, a while maybe.
I'll be fine in a minute. Unless I faint. I'm a bit of a Victorian lady, fainting-wise.
It's a novel. My favorite novel.
It's not that kind of book.
Not so much cold as under-
Welcome to the sweet torture of reading "An Imperial --"
Do you want to talk about it?
I actually think his response is appropriate.
Sometimes people don't understand the promises they're making when they make them.

But that's part of what I like about it. It portrays death truthfully. You die in the middle of your life, in the middle of a sentence. But I do - God, I do want to know what happens to everyone else.
I've written letters. He's never responded. Apparently he moved to Amsterdam, became a recluse. Hasn't published anything. Doesn't do interviews.
What we need is a sequel.
That's what I kept asking Van Houten for in my letters.

"Dear Mr. Peter Van Houten, my name is Hazel Grace Lancaster. My friend Augustus Waters, who read your book - at my recommendation - just received an email from you at this address. I hope you will not mind that he shared that email with me."
"I was wondering if you wouldn't mind answering a few questions I have about what happens after the end of the book. Specifically, the  FOLLOWING:"
"Does Anna's Mom marry the Dutch Tulip Man; is the Dutch Tulip Man up to something - or is he just misunderstood? What happens to Anna's friends?
Lastly, I was hoping you could shed some light on Sisyphus the Hamster.
"I know these are not important literary questions and that your book is full of important literary questions, but I would just really like to know."

"And of course, if ever you do decide to write anything else, even if you don't want to publish it, I'd love to read it. Frankly, I'd read your grocery lists. Yours with great admiration, Hazel Grace Lancaster. Age 16."
Qualities of a Good Nurse. Go.
Gets blood on the first try.
"I'm gonna stab you with this needle now, so there might be a little ouchie."
"Should ever you find yourself in Amsterdam, do pay a visit at your leisure. Yours most sincerely, Peter Van Houten" Son of a - WHAT  IS THIS LIFE!!!
Can we go to Amsterdam? Please?
Mom, no. Please. Don't do anything.
Guilt is definitely a side effect of cancer.
We had fun on that trip.
Is this where you bring all your romantic conquests?
Are you only doing this so I'll kiss you?
Cause I'd totally kiss you either way.
Can we at least ask Dr. Maria?
You said the PET scan was encouraging!
They have doctors in Amsterdam. And cancer. Someone will know what to do.
The Genies can hook it up. They're loaded.
You've never been to Amsterdam, have you Mom?
I'd been poked and stabbed and poisoned for years and still I trod on.
In that moment I would have been very, very happy to die.
Um, I feel like I'm not the most qualified person to answer that.
Can't I just get like a lung transplant or something?
Can I still go to Amsterdam?
So does going to the mall --
I have this opportunity I may never have again. If the medicine's working, I don't see why --

I don't know. I want to go to Amsterdam. And I want him to tell us what happens after the book and I don't want my particular life and also the sky is making me sad and there's this old swing set that my Dad made for me when I was a kid.
That's why I don't have a hamster.
"Lonely, Vaguely Pedophilic Swing Set Seeks Butts of Children."
"Dear Hazel, I have received word via the Genies that you will be visiting us with Augustus Waters and your mother beginning on the 4th. A week away! Peter and I are delighted and cannot wait to --
Did you ever call the Genies to tell them the trip is off? I just got an email from Peter Van Houton's assistant. She still thinks we're coming.
It's called a Cannula. These tubes give me oxygen and help me breathe.
Have you never been on a plane before?
It's a metaphor. He puts the killing thing in his mouth but doesn't give it the power to kill him.
This is what it feels like to ride in a car with you.
Thank you for letting me hijack your wish.
That isn't the suit you wear to funerals?
I have one of those. Bought it for my 15th birthday. Don't think I'd wear it on a date, though.
Van Houten will get it. Trust me.
No it's not. It's a drawing of a pipe. See?
All representations of a thing are inherently abstract. A drawing of a thing is not the thing itself. Nor is a t-shirt of a drawing of a thing the thing itself.
I'm so excited I can barely breathe.
Yes. We - well, Augustus, he made meeting you his Wish so that we could come here and talk to you.
I'm sorry, sir. We don't speak Swedish.
Can we please, maybe, talk about Anna for a sec? I mean, I understand that the story ends mid-
- but that doesn't mean her family and everyone she loves doesn't have a future, right?
I mean, I understand. In a literary sense. But it's impossible NOT to imagine some future --

Hey listen douchepants. You're not gonna tell me anything I don't already know about illness. I need one thing and one thing only from you before I walk out of your life and that's for you to tell me what happens to your goddman characters!
You're really not gonna tell us?
I spent your Wish on that asshole.
It was awful, Mom. You can't imagine.
Then we went to the Anne Frank museum.
I don't think you're dying, Augustus. You've just got a touch of cancer.
How's your love life? Anything from Monica?
She hasn't even like, texted to ask how you're doing?
How do you even know that?
A few days later, Gus landed in the hospital with chest pains.
We have to be a family now.
If you don't mind, I'll just hang for a while.
I think you're special, is that not enough?

You think the only way to live a meaningful life is for everyone to love you, for everyone to remember you. Well guess what, Gus, this is your life. This is all you get. You get me, and your family, and this world. And if that's not enough, well I'm sorry, but it's not nothing. Cause I'll remember you, I'll love you --
It's not over yet, you know.
Oh, thank God. Hi. Hi, I love you!
Gus, what the -- why are you here?
I can't fix this. I have to call someone. I'm sorry.
"The Red Wheelbarrow" by William Carlos Williams.
The problem, of course, is that there's no way of knowing that your last good day is your "Last Good Day." At the time, it's just another decent day.
I can't, I have to meet Gus.

I can't! I can't stay healthy because I'm not healthy, Mom. I am dying. I am going to die and leave you here alone and you won't have me to hover around and you won't be a mother anymore, and I'm sorry, but I can't do anything about it, ok?! Just leave me alone!
I worry that you won't have a life.
So when you're waiting for me outside Support Group or whatever, you're always --
Are you kidding? Mom, this is awesome! This is fantastic! Oh my god!
I'm so excited! You're gonna be so great, Mom!
I know Mom. And I will. I promise.
So, um, what's going on guys?
How did you even get in here?
"I can't talk about our love story so instead I will talk about math.
It was unbearable. The whole thing.

One of the first things they ask you in the ER is to rate your pain on a scale from 1 to 10. I'd been asked this question hundreds of times and I remember once, early on, when I couldn't catch my breath and it felt like my chest was on fire, and the nurse asked me to rate the pain and though I couldn't speak, I held up 9 fingers.
Later on, when I'd been feeling better, the nurse came in and she called me a fighter. "You know how I know," she said. "Because you called a ten a nine."
And this was it. The great and terrible ten.
He loved you so much too.
It's ok, you hear me? It's ok.
There's a beautiful quote in Gus's home that reads "if you want the rainbow, you gotta deal with the rain."
I didn't believe a word, of course.
You read your fan mail now?
I'm so not in the mood --
Nope. Thanks though. Have a great life.
I remind a lot of people of a lot of people.
Well I'm sorry for your loss.
You didn't ruin our trip, you asshole. We had an awesome trip.
You think I care about that? I don't give a shit, Van Houten.
You're a drunk and a jerk and a failure. And I'd like you to get out of my car right now so I can go home and grieve.
He was really fighting for breath, I guess. He eventually went unconscious, but it seems like, yeah, it wasn't great or anything.
I didn't find it that annoying.
He is not my friend and -- how do you know about that?
Yeah well I'm over it. I never want to read another word of that asshole's again.
Did he give it to you?
I'm sure he'll call, don't worry.
Dr. Maria called today. The PET Scan is set for the eighth.
I told you Support Group was a good idea.
Are you out of your mind?
It's too much, Haze. We can't accept something like that from a virtual stranger.
They thought it was a brain tumor.
Drained a liter and a half last night.
This is just a thing Hazel. It's a thing we can live with.
I won't be a mom anymore.
I'm not supposed to tell you until your father gets home.
Dr. Maria called last night and made a convincing case that you need to live --
I'm getting back in the tub now.
Just so you know, I'm right here.
What? I like watching you sleep.
I promise I'll do crazy Mom stuff tonight while you and Gus are at dinner.
You have reservations at a place called Oranjee. Mr. Van Houten set it up. Very fancy according to the Book. And romantic.
I really don't get that shirt.
When did you get so grown up? I feel like it was yesterday I was telling 8-year old Hazel why the sky was blue. You thought I was a genius back then.
You have to eat, Hazel. You're not gonna starve yourself to death just because Gus is sick. You have to stay healthy --
You heard me say that to your father?
Oh god, sweetie. I'm sorry. I was wrong, ok? It wasn't true. It's not something I believe.
As long as either of us is alive, I will be your mother. Even if you die, I --
Even when you die, I will still be your mother. I will always be your Mother.
I don't just sit around, you know.
I'm taking some classes. Online. To get my master's in social work.
Thank you. That means everything to me.
I'd still really like you to eat.
Are you sure? We can drive you --
I may switch you to Zoloft. Or Lexapro. And twice a day instead of once.
Have you been going to that Support Group I suggested?
Just give it a chance, ok? For me.
Who would like to share their story with the group?
Who else would like to share?
And how are you doing Hazel?
And does your friend want to speak?
And how are you feeling Augustus?
Perhaps you'd like to share your fears with the group, Augustus.
Would, uh, anyone like to speak to that?
This is a really good show.
Of course we can, we're your parents.
Hazel, you need to get out of the house. Make friends. Be a teenager.
Would you like to be excused?
Is that a Rik Smits jersey?
She'll want to keep up with you -
Why don't you go home, get some rest?
I love you. I'm so proud of you.
Mrs. Waters told us the night before you left.
Hazel. You of all people know it's possible to live with pain.
It was a privilege to love him, though, wasn't it?
Gives you an idea how we feel about you.
A small Episcopalian sanctuary in suburban Indianapolis.
Hazel walks towards the elevator. An EXTREMELY SICK LOOKING KID holds it open for her. Hazel thinks better of it.
Hazel catches her breath. Shakes her head. Surprised at herself.
She didn't want to do it after the surgery. Said she couldn't handle it. I'm about to lose my eyesight and she can't handle it.
Right, sure, but you keep the promise anyway. That's what love is. Love is keeping the promise anyway.
Did she really just say "you'll see?"
That is huge. I mean, seriously, is this my freakin' arm or a dartboard? Three - no condescending voice.
I don't know. To be honest, I think a hell of a lot more about Monica than my eye. Is that crazy? That's crazy.
But I believe in love, you know? I don't believe that everybody gets to keep their eyes or not get sick or whatever, but everybody should have true love. Don't you think?
But you don't want to hook up with him?
Great. Wonderful. I mean, they're not in my head is the only problem.
Did you write his eulogy yet?
I'm blind but I'm not that blind.
My throw was to the left or I should aim to the left?
"Augustus Waters talked so much that he'd interrupt you at his own funeral. And he was pretentious.
Sweet Jesus that kid never took a piss without pondering the resonances of human waste production. And he was vain. But that comes with superhuman handsomeness."

"But I will say this: when the scientists of the future show up at my house with robot eyes and they tell me to try them on, I will tell the scientists to piss off, because I don't even want to see a world without Augustus Waters."
Can I get a hand here, Hazel?
Of all the things I've lost in my life, this hurts the most.
Do you know if it hurt or whatever?
Gus really loved you, you know.
He wouldn't shut up about it.
Did you read the note or whatever from your author friend?
We talked at the cemetery. Said he came all this way to give you that.
Yeah but he didn't write it - Gus did.
I do it all the time. Go.
But really I'm just here at Isaac's request.
Me? Oh I'm grand. I'm on a roller coaster that only goes up, my friend.
I thought we were in a church basement but apparently we were literally in the heart of Jesus.

I enjoy looking at beautiful people and I decided a while back not to deny myself the simpler pleasures of existence. Particularly given that, as you so astutely pointed out, we're all gonna die pretty soon.
"Always" is their thing. They'll "always" love each other and whatnot. Must have texted "always"
They don't hurt you unless you light them.
It's a metaphor. See? You put the thing that kills you between your teeth. But you don't give it the power to do the killing.
I failed the test a couple times.
These are mine. And these. The rest of it's just cancer perks.
Not your cancer story. Your story.
Don't tell me you're one of those people who becomes their disease.
I reject that out of hand.
Think of something you love. First thing that comes to mind.
I love it when you talk medical to me.
Dude! Hey! Does Support Group Hazel make this better or worse?
How fast can you get here?
Isaac, Hazel from Support Group is coming downstairs.
A gentle reminder: Isaac is in the midst of a psychotic episode.
You look nice, by the way.
Seems Isaac and Monica are no longer a going concern.
He just wants to cry and play video games.
I've been wanting to call you on a nearly minutely basis but I have been waiting until I could form a coherent thought in re: "An Imperial Affliction."
I can't stop thinking about it.
The only problem is the ending.
It's torture! I mean, I totally get that she died or whatever - Anna.
I've been looking for a way to tell my Dad that I kinda hate basketball. Think maybe we've found it.
Yes. We need to know what happens to Anna's family after she dies.
I found his assistant. I emailed her. She must have forwarded it to him.

"To answer your question: No, I have not written anything else, nor will I. I do not feel that continuing to share my thoughts with readers would benefit either them or me. However thank you again for your generous email. Yours most sincerely, Peter Van Houten.
Hazel Grace, could I, with my meager intellectual capabilities, make up a letter from the great Peter Van Houten?
Tell me you did not go to Disney World.
Hazel Grace! You did not use your one dying Wish to go to Disney World!
That is the saddest thing I've ever heard!
How can I have a crush on a girl with such cliche wishes?
How would you like to go on a picnic?
Didn't cut this fella off for the hell of it. Though it is an excellent weight-loss strategy.
Probably why I'm still a virgin.
And he is. Much like Rik Smits. And tulips.
How cool is that? A skeleton being used as a playground.
You're probably wondering why you're sitting here eating a bad cheese sandwich and drinking orange juice with a guy in a Rik Smits jersey.
Hush! I'm in the midst of a grand soliloquy here.

You were young. Impressionable. The Grim Reaper staring you in the face. And the fear of dying with your one true Wish left ungranted led you to rush into making one you didn't really want, for how could little Hazel Grace, having never read "An Imperial Affliction" ever know that her one TRUE wish was to visit Mr. Peter Van Houten in his Amsterdamian exile.
If you were smart, you would have saved your wish til the time in your life when you really knew your true self.
Got it in exchange for the leg.

I'm not gonna give you my Wish or anything. But I too have an interest in meeting Peter Van Houten and it wouldn't make much sense to meet him without the girl who introduced me to his book, now would it?
I talked to the Genies and they're in total agreement.
They won't let me in. Family only.
I demand to see this swing set of tears.
That is one sad swing set.
All efforts to save me from you will fail.
Is this about Amsterdam? Cause we  DON'T --
I get it. One day you're going to explode in a huge ball of fire and everyone close to you will die in your wake.
There's already two people in your life you're going to destroy. Why add a third to that list. Am I right?
We have got to do something about this frigging swing set.
"Desperately Lonely Swing Set Needs Loving Home."
BECAUSE IT'S MY LIFE, MOM. IT  BELONGS TO ME!
Always a pleasure to see you ma'am.
I'll be right down the hall.
And can we get more of this?
Thank you for coming to Amsterdam.
Thank you for wearing that dress which is like whoa.
I want this dragon carrot risotto to become a person so I can take it to Vegas and marry it.
Oh no. That one's not nearly this nice.
When I first found out I was sick -
So right before the surgery I asked my parents if I could buy a suit, like a really nice suit, just in case I didn't make it.
Oh for sure. I mean, not like a heaven where you ride unicorns, play harps, and live in a mansion made of clouds but, yeah, I believe in something.
Something becomes of us. It has to.

I'm in love with you. And I know that love is just a shout into the void, and that oblivion is inevitable, and that we're all doomed and that there will come a day when all our labor has been returned to dust, and I know the sun will swallow the only earth we'll ever have, and I am in love with you.
Maybe he can't hear over the music?
Incidentally, thank you for dinner last night.
Is this some kind of performance?
I don't know what's going on.
I will. Better than any shit that drunk could write. With blood and guts and sacrifice. You'll love it.
You did not spend it on him. You spent it on us.
I'm not going anywhere with that monster.
We're at the top. That's it.
It tapers a little and then it's just skin --
I love you too, Hazel Grace.
"I can't stand up, I'm too drunk."
Don't you worry about me, Hazel Grace. I'll find a way to hang around and annoy you for a long time.
I don't suppose you can forget about it, treat me like I'm not dying.
Would it be absolutely ludicrous to make out right now?
Would you be kind enough to whip something up?
Do you happen to have four dollars?
Who cares where she is? This is not about her. This is about you.
No you missed it by like 20 feet.

Hello ma'am. Your daughter has done an injustice and we've come here seeking revenge. We may not look like much. Between the three of us, we have five legs, four eyes, and two and a half working lungs.
But we also have two dozen eggs. So If I was you, I would go back inside.
It's a good life, Hazel Grace.
No! Please! Hazel, listen to me. Do not call 911 or my parents -- I'll never forgive you -- Don't, please.
I wanted to buy some cigarettes. I lost my pack. Or they took it.
Quick question for you. Did you ever write that eulogy I asked you to prepare?
Excellent. Do you think you could find yourself at the Literal Heart of Jesus in 20 minutes.
I wanted to attend my funeral. By the way, will you speak at my funeral?
Sweet. I'm hopeful I'll get to attend as a ghost, but just to make sure, I thought I'd - well, not to put you on the spot, but I thought I'd arrange a pre-funeral.
Would you believe they leave the door open at night?
Hey don't swear in the Literal Heart of Jesus.
Hazel Grace, it's down to you.
13-YEAR OLD HAZEL on the operating table. It's a nightmare.
The sun shines in the room. 14-year old Hazel eats ice chips, the color has returned to her cheeks.
Hazel, in a hospital gown, is slowly fed through the machine.
The doctors are trying to be delicate here.
Hazel walks with Isaac out of Support Group.
A SKYCAP helps Hazel, Gus and Frannie with all their bags and equipment.
Would they help me breathe too?
Thanks for letting me try it.
Sir, you can't smoke on this plane.
That metaphor is prohibited on today's flight.
Indiana. They steal from the Indians but the keep the name, yes?
Yes and no. Amsterdam is like the rings of a tree. It gets older as you get closer to the center.
Your table, Mr. And Mrs. Waters.
Do you know what Dom Perignon said after he invented champagne?
Welcome to Oranjee. Would you like a menu or will you have the chef's choice?
We have bottled all the stars for you this evening, my young friends.
Belgian white asparagus with a lavender infusion.
Your meal has been paid for by Mr.
She says, "the beautiful couple is beautiful!"
A crisp Spring morning in Amsterdam. The buzz in the air outside is equalled by the buzz in:  69.
Where Hazel excitedly paces through the room.
You know why I left America, Lidewij? To never have to encounter Americans. Get rid of them.
Which of you is Augustus Waters?
Yours are the first missives to which I've replied and look where that got me.
Just me then, Lidewij. Scotch and soda.
She thinks I have a drinking problem.
Did you dress like her on purpose?
I do not have a drinking problem. I have a Churchillian relationship with alcohol: I can crack jokes and govern England and do anything I want to do. Except not drink.
We bought them dinner last night?
How familiar are you with Swedish hip-hop?
But presumably you know Afasi Och Filthy's seminal album "Flacken."
Who the hell speaks Swedish? The important thing is not what nonsense the voices are saying, but what the voices are feeling.

Rudolf Otto said that if you had not encountered the numinous then his work was not for you. And I say to you, my friends, if you cannot hear Afasi Och Filthy's bravadic response to fearfulness, then my work is not for you.
Let us imagine that you are racing a tortoise.
The tortoise has a ten yard head start. In the time it takes you to run ten yards, the tortoise has moved maybe one yard. And so on, forever.

You are faster than the tortoise but you can never catch him, you see, you can only decrease his lead. Now certainly you can run past the tortoise as long as you don't contemplate the mechanics involved but the question of how turns out to be so complicated that no one really solved it until Cantor's proof that some infinities are bigger than other infinities.
I assume that answers your questions.
And yet you seemed so intelligent in print, Mr. Waters.
Must be all that cancer in your brain.
I'm not interested in talking about that book.
Nothing happens to them! They're fictions. They cease to exist the moment the novel is over.
I can't do this. Lidewij, get rid of them, please.
I won't indulge your childish whims. I refuse to pity you in the manner in which you're accustomed.
Replies.Didascalie: (Lidewij doesn't move, he turns back to Hazel)

Replies.Reply: Of course you do. Like all sick kids, your existence depends on it.
You are fated to live out your days as the child you were when diagnosed, the child who believes there is life after a novel ends.
You are a side effect of an evolutionary process that cares little for individual lives.
You are a failed experiment in mutation.
Lidewij. I'll have a martini please.
I'd like you to leave now.
Have you ever stopped to ask why you care so much about your silly questions?
We need to fake pray now.
Just to the bottom of the hill.
The drinks are free drinks in First Class.
Your boy Waters and I corresponded quite a bit in his last --

I would hardly call him a fan. He despised me. But he was quite insistent I attend his funeral and tell you what became of Anna and her mother. So here I am and that's your answer: omnis cellula e cellula.
Not when she died, no. I was insufferable long before Anna, my dear. Grief doesn't change you, Hazel, it reveals you.
And I'm sorry for yours. I'm sorry for everything, for being so rude to you two, for ruining your trip --
Please. I am sorry. Come in.
Fan mail. 18 years worth. He never opens it.
I also think the Earth is round.
Perhaps we can do some sightseeing.
No, there are many stairs. Steep stairs.
This is the bookcase that hid the Frank family and four others.
The only member of the whole family to survive was Otto, Anne's father.
I don't know how you go on, without your family.
Gus wakes up in the bed. He looks around for Hazel but she isn't there. On the bed is a piece of paper. A note.
Hazel and Gus sit with Frannie drinking coffee in the sun at an outdoor cafe. They're re-enacting yesterday's events.
The place is filled today with mourners for Augustus Waters.
I think we're ready to begin.
Now I call on Augustus's close friend Isaac to say a few words.
What a load of shit, eh kid?
Everyone is watching Gus's body be lowered into the ground.
Hazel sits against the tub on the floor and weeps. Soon there's a knock.
Hazel sits up. Her heart is racing.
Gus stealthily sneaks into Hazel's single room in the ICU.
